title: Transparency
nrbc: Canonical Value | Moral Drive of Accountability and Trust
summary:
Definition (Stanford + Oxford Synthesis):
Transparency is the ethical and procedural commitment to making information, decisions, intentions, and systems visible, comprehensible, and reviewable to relevant stakeholders. It requires that data flows, algorithms, institutional logic, and outcomes are not hidden behind obfuscation or complexity. In moral terms, it serves as a prerequisite for informed consent, accountability, and meaningful oversight.

AI Ethics Implications:
In AI systems, transparency enables:

Interpretability of algorithmic decisions

Auditing of system behavior and outcomes

Detection of bias, drift, or misuse

Democratization of knowledge, reducing power imbalances between developers, regulators, and users
It is often operationalized through explainable AI (XAI), documentation standards, model cards, and transparent governance logs.

title: Responsibility
nrbc: Canonical Value | Regulatory and Behavioral Drive
summary: Responsibility refers to the obligation of agents—human or artificial—to account for their actions, outcomes, and influence. In AI ethics, this includes role-based accountability, liability chains, and clearly attributed decision pathways.

title: Non-Maleficence
nrbc: Canonical Value | Normative Foundation of Safety and Precaution
summary: Non-Maleficence is the principle of 'do no harm.' In AI systems, it guides safety constraints, precautionary design, and harm-avoidance in autonomous and high-stakes environments such as healthcare, transport, and law

title: Inclusivity
summary: Inclusivity is the proactive effort to ensure representation, access, and participation across diverse populations. In AI, it mandates inclusive data sets, accessibility standards, and the prevention of exclusionary or biased system outputs.

title: Trust
nrbc: Canonical Value | Relational and Trustworthiness Norm
summary: Trust involves justified reliance on an entity's competence, intention, and consistency. In AI, it relates to user confidence in system reliability, predictability, and alignment with human values.

title: Ethical Responsibility
nrbc: Canonical Value | Meta-Governance and Lifecyce Justification
summary: Ethical Responsibility captures the duty to act in morally appropriate ways within the lifecycle of AI. This includes ethical design, deployment, oversight, and decision justification across all actors and stages.

title: Privacy
nrbc: Canonical Value | Privacy Ethics Foundation and System Boundary Enforce
summary: Privacy is the right to control personal information and be protected from unwarranted surveillance. In AI ethics, it frames data minimization, consent-based models, and protection against profiling and behavioral inference.

title: Innovation
nrbc: Canonical Value | Conceptual and System-Level Driver
summary: Innovation is the value that drives creative transformation, progress, and responsible experimentation. In AI, it supports the ethical exploration of new capabilities while ensuring alignment with societal values and human oversight.

title: Sustainability
nrbc: Canonical Value | Environmental and Futures Alignment Layer
summary: Sustainability ensures that the development, deployment, and impact of AI systems preserve ecological, economic, and social viability over time. It guides long-term thinking, resource stewardship, and intergenerational responsibility.

title: Dignity
nrbc: Canonical Value | Identity and Dignity Protection Layer
summary: Dignity upholds the inherent worth of every individual. In AI ethics, it governs design practices that avoid dehumanization, preserve self-respect, and enable equitable treatment regardless of background or status.

title: Collaboration
nrbc: Canonical Value | Relational and Cooperative Governance Layer
summary: Collaboration fosters cooperative intelligence, shared agency, and interdependent decision-making. In AI, it facilitates teamwork between humans and machines, interdisciplinary design, and multistakeholder governance.

title: Autonomy
nrbc: Canonical Value | Personal Agency and Consent Enabler
summary: Autonomy is the capacity of individuals to act with self-governance and informed consent. In AI, it supports systems that respect user choices, cognitive liberty, and personal sovereignty in interaction.

title: Human Rights
nrbc: Canonical Value | Universal Rights Enforcement Layer
summary: Human Rights frame the universal entitlements to liberty, privacy, protection, and participation. In AI ethics, they are invoked in algorithmic fairness, surveillance boundaries, and inclusion in decision processes.

title: Beneficence
nrbc: Canonical Value | Human Welfare and Well-being Driver
summary: Beneficence commits to promoting well-being, welfare, and positive outcomes. In AI design, this principle underlies systems that enhance health, education, prosperity, and human flourishing.
